channel.title: PS3 and/or xbox360 Emulation
channel.description: Will it happen any time soon? Why or why not? Personally I don't know two shits about the subject, but I think it'd be really cool to play newer Halo games and shit on a pc.

item.title: PS3 and/or xbox360 Emulation
item.dc:creator: loony636
item.description:
Ramirezoid:

No More Heroes runs at a snail’s pace on dolphin. There are no other games on the Wii worth playing.

I would bring a more holistic rebuttal, but I’m far too tired. Instead, here’s a lst you should try (read: try, not: “absolutely the best games in the universe that will reverse all of your preconceptions about the Wii”):

  • Resident Evil 4: Wii Edition (The Wiimote makes it about a billion times better)
  • Trauma Centre: New Blood
  • Mad World
  • New Super Mario Bros. Wii
  • Donkey Kong Country Returns
  • House of the Dead: Overkill
  • Mario Strikers: Charged
  • Super Mario Galaxy 1 & 2
  • Metroid Prime (haven’t tried the Wii-ified versions of the original 2, but they look okay)
  • Mario Kart Wii (I would HOPE you’ve already tried it, but it takes everything that was bad about Double Dash and removes it)
  • Super Smash Brothers Brawl (SO many hours of fun was had here)
  • Zelda: Twilight Princess
  • WarioWare: Smooth Moves

There are a few more, but I don’t have them in my collection. Anyway, they’re some of the better/different ones which are worth trying if you’ve got a Wii sitting in the corner with nothing to do. Of course there’s Homebrew (which is the main function my Wii serves now) which have a slew of emulators and games to try out, but these are some of the actual games you should try. Can’t speak for any of the shop titles since I don’t have the moola to try them out (except Defend Your Castle looks line insane fun).

Read full topic

item.title: PS3 and/or xbox360 Emulation
item.dc:creator: Siggs
item.description:
OldDirtyBastard:

Sixaxis via motioninjoy > xbox 360 controller

I never got the success of the dualshock. It doesn’t fit in my hands well, the joysticks have horrible feel and are badly placed, and in the PS3 iteration, the triggers are shit. Lots of travel, tiny analogue.

Read full topic

item.title: PS3 and/or xbox360 Emulation
item.dc:creator: Weasel
item.description:
Heh, I play Wii games and gamecube games on dolphin in 1080p(strangely, the only game I have had trouble with FPS-wise is Metal Gear Solid : The Twin Snakes) which is a higher resolution than the Wii/gamecube can output, and it shows.
I also enjoy playing some PS2 games using PCSX2, and MGS3 runs around 60FPS with few graphical glitches, but the one big glitch is that water reflections are bugged to shit. It is most certainly playable, and a great game to top that off.
I use a Intel C2Q q6600 overclocked to 3,6GHz and a GTX 460 (also OC:d). I’m thinking of buying a new rig soon though, getting a i5 2500k and clocking that shit to 4,6-5GHz. That would probably run MGS3 at a high FPS using software mode, lol.

Read full topic

item.title: PS3 and/or xbox360 Emulation
item.dc:creator: TheSuperNova
item.description:
I have the dolphin emulator, emulates the gamecube and the Wii, though the latter I never use. i have a quad core at 3.2GHz and it’s pretty slow in a lot of games, though the ones that are important work fine. also, using a 360 pad is nice, and the games that do run well allow me to use custom texture packs and anti-aliasing.

item.title: PS3 and/or xbox360 Emulation
item.dc:creator: OldDirtyBastard
item.description:
Okay.
Here’s how it should look:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VWeXfilavu0
Here’s how it looks in emu using the hardware mode (3:53).
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vw8HIdm9yfc&feature=related
Software mode displays it (and the whole game) properly. Especially DX10. But we all how fucking slow that is. And no bonuses in regard of high res.
That’s where mega overclocked CPUs come in. You’ll probably need sandy bridge Core i7 cllocked @ at least 4 ghz.

EDIT: more explanation:

pcsx2 boards:

Believe in it or not, MGS3 isn’t as playable as most people say it is…
Sure, you can play from start to end with 50-60fps in most areas, but only if you are willing to lose 50% of the way the developers intended you to see the game.

I’ll explain:

To play the game at its fullest, unless you have a real powerfull CPU, you’ll probably have to use your GPU, what means hardware mode on GSdx… What is natural, if: GSdx on hardware mode supported MGS3. It doesn’t really, you’ll loose lots of effects (reflections on water [actually you’ll end up with some colored garbage], full-screen shading/bloom/color-correction, radio pictures/effects).

In other words, if you really want to play the game as it should be, you’ll have to use software mode, that cuts fps by half, and makes it slow in most machines.

Just Open the game and press F9 to see the difference between software and hardware mode.
I would wait a little more for GSdx to fully support it. MGS deserves to be played like the developers intended

But if you really must insist, these are my settings:
GSdx: Make sure you use Native, all other options use default.
CPU: Disable MicroVU, as far as I know, it makes no difference on MGS3
SpeedHacks: Play around with cycle rate, usually for me it makes the game slower. Emotion Engine hacks I use all, VU Cycle Stealing at almost full.

Works fast in hardware mode, fully playable. But the graphics loose lot of its charm, as I said.

And as far as I know, pcsx2 doesn’t utilize more than 2 cores - because the devs say that controlling 2 cores is hard enough. :
Reason why I mentioned i7 is because it’s faster than Core Duo on the same speed.

Read full topic

item.title: PS3 and/or xbox360 Emulation
item.dc:creator: FireTime
item.description:
Well my guess would be due to graphical glitches, I’ve noticed that most 3d games that have 2d or sprite based segments/screens tend to have the most graphical glitches (even on some games with the n64) due to the qwirky way they they were drawn on the original systems. (some n64 games just placed a 2d plane infront of the camera but pj64 has clipping issues so you can’t see objects that are too close to the camera.)
